At that time, Venerable Ä€rÄá¸a knew that the Bodhisattva's mind had attained virtue, and further expounded his own doctrine of the definitive conclusion, speaking in verse:
Gautama Åšramaá¹‡a, listen well, in my doctrine I speak of the general conclusion,
Although now you are in the midst of afflictions, later you will naturally return to liberation.
At that time, after Ä€rÄá¸a had spoken this verse, he said:
'Sentient beings have two meanings:
One is inherent nature, the other is transformation. Combining these two, they are collectively called sentient beings.
As for inherent nature, it refers to the five great elements. The five great elements are earth, water, fire, wind, and space. I and the formless are called the inherent nature of the essence.
As for transformation, it refers to the faculties, objects, hands, feet, speech, movement, coming and going, as well as the mind and consciousness. This is called transformation.
If one knows such objects, it is called knowing objects. As for being able to know those objects, it is said by the wise that this is knowing the self.
He spoke a verse, saying:
If one can recognize the faculties and objects, it is called well knowing those objects.
As for knowing all objects, the wise say it is knowing through contemplation.
At that time, Ä€rÄá¸a said thus:
'The one who contemplates the self is the sage Kapila and his disciples. They measure this mental realm. The son of the sage PajÄpati, named GambhÄ«rÄrtha, also sees it this way.
Just as a person repeatedly experiences birth, old age, sickness, and death, and deeply understands the suffering and harm, and explains it to others.
Thinking of being far away from this principle, one should understand that all are signless.
It is also said:
The cause of afflictions refers to ignorance and attachment to various karmas.
Such karmas belong to the cause of afflictions.
This cause of afflictions has four kinds. This person cannot be liberated from birth and death, because he has not yet escaped from various afflictions.
What are the four kinds?
First, lack of faith; second, attachment to self; third, having doubts; fourth, lack of concentration.
Because of having remnants, there are no skillful means. Deeply attached to the world, one always falls.
For this reason, one receives birth in various places.
As for lack of faith, one always acts contrary to what one should know. This is called lack of faith.
The one who speaks of attachment to self says, 'This is mine,' and 'That is not mine.' I speak like this, I receive like this, I go, I stay.
My characteristics, my body, such is my name. Not self-aware, this is called attachment to self.
The one who speaks of having doubts, this is doubting everything without confusion, this is just one thing.
Just like a lump of mud, this is called doubt.

The one who speaks of having no fixed position says, 'It is like this, it is like that,' 'This is so,' 'That is so,' 'This is not so,' 'That is not so.' Mind, thought, and all karmic activities, this is the multitude, this is me, this is him, this is here. This is called having no fixed position.
Moreover, the remaining ones, not yet knowing the superior state, not yet awakened, not yet realizing the intrinsic nature, just beginning to realize and know, this is called the remaining ones.
Furthermore, those who say they lack skillful means are ignorant. Because of ignorance, they do not understand skillful means. Because they lack skillful means, they are unable to reveal [the truth].
For this reason, they are called those who lack skillful means.
Those who are attached are ignorant people who, upon seeing, hearing, touching, or perceiving, give rise to attachment.

Sometimes the mind is attached, the body is attached, and speech is attached. Or the mental activity is attached to all objects, and they are confused and attached to what should not be attached to. This is called attachment.
Those who fall are those who think 'this is that place' and 'that place is this.' Those who have such thoughts are called those who fall.
For this reason, they fall into afflictions. This is called having no virtue and being ignorant.
This is called the five places where there is suffering and no joy. This is a place of no joy.
Namely, darkness, ignorance, and great ignorance. There are two mixed abodes. This is called the five places.
As for darkness, it refers to laziness;
As for ignorance, it refers to birth and death;
As for great ignorance, it refers to engaging in desire.
Why is this so?
Even if there are greatly virtuous people in this place, they are still deluded and do not know how to awaken, and therefore it is called great ignorance.
As for the two kinds of mixed dwelling, it refers to anger;
There are also two kinds of mixed dwelling, which refer to laziness.
Ignorant beings do not cultivate in this way, and are confused and attached to these five places. They dwell in the ocean of afflictions and suffering, following the current of birth and death.
I see, I hear, I realize, I create, I teach others to create, I go like this, and because of this kind of mind and this kind of intention, I revolve and sink in the ocean of afflictions.
In this way, these four kinds entwine and wrap up in afflictions, saying there are no causes and effects.
Greatly Virtuous Gautama!
You should know these kinds of things.
And spoke this verse:
If a person wishes to attain right view and knowledge, the pure liberation of the four dhyanas,
If the mind awakens to that wisdom, they will know the true sages and what is not true.
As explained above, it should be proclaimed, therefore it is called the understanding of the four dhyanas,
Able to abandon all practices and non-practice, this is called knowing the nameless and wordless.ğŸ”½Because of this, in that place the Great Brahma Heaven,
Explains the brahma-conduct of the world,ğŸ”½If one is able to practice this brahma-conduct,
One will be born in the palace of Brahma.'
At that time, the Bodhisattva, having heard this kind of speech from Aralara, further asked again:

'The practice of skillful means, if practicing skillful means, the place one reaches, and the practice of brahma-conduct, the place of practice and the Dharma to be practiced, Venerable One, please explain everything to me.'
At that time, Arahant relied on his own general discussion of the principles and essence, and all of them spoke to the Bodhisattva, saying:
'Virtuous Gautama!
If you wish to practice, you should abandon the palace, rely on the way of leaving home, beg for food to sustain your life, make great vows, cultivate precepts, and abide in contentment.
According to your ability, provide for clothing, food, bedding, and a quiet dwelling place. Walk and sit alone.

As in the treatises, what is known and seen by wisdom, the faults of greed, anger, and delusion, having seen them, abandon them from afar, detest desires, and experience the greatest happiness. Control the senses and enter meditation.
At that time, far from desires, far from troubles, in a secluded place, give rise to separation from discrimination, and attain the first meditation.
Having attained the first meditation, still think and contemplate in this way, gradually attaining joy. Having attained joy, abide in this tranquil concentration.

Relying on the power of this concentration, the mind deeply detests desire, anger, and so forth. Having repeatedly detested them, the mind turns to delight. Having increased delight, wisdom grows. At this time, one attains rebirth in the palace of MahÄbrahmÄ.
Having been born there, one again thinks and discriminates like this: This disturbs my wisdom. One then abandons it. Having abandoned it, one attains the second dhyÄna and gives rise to great joy.
Having attained joy, one sees that the mind is oppressed by great joy and seeks something superior. One then reaches the Ä€bhÄsvara Heaven.
Having reached the Ä€bhÄsvara Heaven and seen the place of receiving happiness, having reached there, one detests the joy and happiness.

There are also people who, due to a mind of self-conceit, seek the characteristics of liberation, wishing to transcend the fruits of the four dhyÄnas. At that time, he immediately attained the boundless discernment of the space within his body. In all these forms and within the forms, and in all the objects such as trees and so forth, he discerned boundless space. He attained the clear discernment of all these places of form, and having discerned boundless space, he then realized the sphere of mastery.
There is a verse that goes:
Thus, in this subtle and great Brahma realm, all are formless and always silent.

At that time, Alara again said:

In the past, the sages such as Rishi Sha (Skt. Jina), Vyushita (Skt. Vishesha), and Parasara (Skt. Parashara), as well as other sages, all praised and taught this liberated Dharma, and also rode this liberated Dharma to attain liberation.

At that time, the Bodhisattva heard the teachings of the Brahma-conduct from the sage Alara, accepted and practiced them, and in order to practice the conduct of a sramana and seek the fruit of a sramana, he practiced this Dharma and immediately realized it.

At that time, the Bodhisattva went further to where Ä€rÄá¸a KÄlÄma was and said these words:

Having said this, at that time Ä€rÄá¸a replied to the Bodhisattva, saying:

The Bodhisattva further said:
I have heard this Dharma from the Venerable One. As you have said, I believe and know that I have realized this Dharma.
If there is a wise one who knows the realm of practice, he should also not abandon such a Dharma.
However, what I see is that although this Dharma is wonderful, it is not ultimately complete.
Why is it so?

I think and contemplate like this: this Dharma still has a time of change. But the nature of this realm is like this. Knowing this, although this wisdom is not true wisdom, I still want to give rise to other dharmas.

However, what the Venerable One said is that although it is said that I have attained pure liberation, if I contemplate and observe this conditioned arising Dharma, when encountering conditions, it will arise again, not true liberation. It is like a seed that is planted at the wrong time and stored in the ground. If it does not accord with the right time and lacks water and rain, the sprout will not grow.
If it is planted at the right time, moistened and adjusted, and all conditions are fully combined, it will grow.

Now this is also like this. It is just because of ignorance that one clings to the Dharma of love and so on. Having abandoned this, one distinguishes and says that one is liberated. But there is still clinging to self, which must all be abandoned.

They then abandon this ignorant love and so forth, and the karma that does not accord with this. Although they attain what is superior to before, they have not yet reached the true place, but only practice the place where there is a self through discrimination.

Because of those subtle three things coming together, and because of those subtle afflictions, there is again a separate place of non-use, with a long lifespan, and because of discrimination, they say, I have attained liberation.

Just as the color and heat of fire, heat is not separate from color, color is not separate from heat. The substance of these two is originally non-existent. If they were to combine, there is no such possibility.
Just as my self is, all afflictions are like this.
After attaining liberation, reaching that place, one is bound again, because of using wisdom to grasp objects.
After extinguishing form, there is only consciousness. Knowing that my consciousness is called existence.
Because of this existence, it is not called liberation.

For this reason, why bother with discrimination?
This self is not self, like wood, like a wall, repeatedly abandoning each other.
Since each one is layered upon the other, there is wisdom. Therefore, I contemplate that all objects should be let go of, so that one can attain self-benefit.'
And he spoke a verse, saying:
'Layer upon layer, all should be abandoned, this is called letting go of objects,
Because all faculties and objects are let go of, this is called benefiting oneself and benefiting others.'

The Bodhisattva replied:

Freely able to enter, revolving within birth and death, not staying for a moment, those dharmas and non-dharmas, those gods, humans, and various destinies, those able to travel far, those able to make a vehicle, riding that vehicle, able to cross the deep ocean of existence, revolving back and forth, able to create birth and death, also able to transform, freely supreme, most wonderful and great, able to be the lord of the world, transforming and subduing all.
The Bodhisattva asked:

Arahant said:

If the self-existent one transforms this world, then one cannot see the successive arising of things. The wheel of afflictions should not turn in such a sequence, and sentient beings' minds should not naturally attain sharpness.

Sentient beings should have no basis to rely on, no place to seek, and nothing to do.
